titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Daisy Aldan Papers
titlestmt.author: by Andrea Benefiel and Molly Wheeler

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday May 4, 2019 at 03:06

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (104 boxes) + 3 portfolios, 4 broadside folders, 5 art storage objects
did.abstract: The Daisy Aldan Papers document the work of poet, editor, educator, translator, and filmmaker Daisy Aldan. The papers consist of personal and professional correspondence, drafts of writings, writings of others, notebooks, diaries, teaching material, artwork, audiovisual material, photographs, printed material, and personal papers spanning the years 1919 to 2000.

langmaterial.language: In English, German, French, and Spanish.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Daisy Aldan, 1983-2000. Gift of Diana Cohen, 1992. Purchased from the Argosy Book Store on the Elizabeth Wakeman Dwight Memorial Fund, 1999. Purchased from Charles Apfelbaum on the Elizabeth Wakeman Dwight Memorial Fund, 2005.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 31-32, 35-36, 106-110 and 116 (sound and video recordings): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 94-97 (motion picture film): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 33-34, 98-105 and 115 (reel-to-reel sound recordings): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Daisy Aldan Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Daisy Aldan Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections [as they are acquired], and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
The collection received preliminary processing at the time of acquisition. Further organization, rehousing, and description were carried out in 2012.

The collection is comprised of material formerly classed as: Uncat ZA MS 100, Uncat ZA MS 137, Uncat ZA MS 244, Uncat ZA File 251, Uncat ZA MS 82, Uncat ZA File 283, Uncat ZA MS 283, Uncat ZA MS 269, Uncat ZA MS 273, Uncat MSS 604, Uncat ZA MS 289, Uncat ZA MS 288, Uncat ZA MS 440, Uncat ZA File 347, Uncat ZA MS 539, Uncat ZA MS 551, Uncat ZA MS 639, Uncat ZA MS 639, Uncat MSS 95, and Uncat MSS 779. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below, according to month and year of acquisition.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during basic processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Daisy Aldan (1923-2001)
bioghist.p: Daisy Aldan, American poet, editor, educator, translator, and filmmaker.

Aldan was born in 1923 in New York City to designer Louis Aldan and actress Esther Edelheit Aldan. She was a child actor on the CBS radio program, Let's Pretend , and was first published in the pages of Poetry at age twelve. Aldan stayed in New York City, where she received a Bachelor of Arts from Hunter College in 1943, a Master of Arts from Brooklyn College in 1948, and took graduate coursework at New York University. Her publications included her first chapbook of poems (1946), The Destruction of Cathedrals and Other Poems (1963) and Seven: Seven (Poems and Photographs) (1965) and several books of experimental poetry published in the 1970s. In 1979, with the assistance of a National Endowment for the Arts grant, she published the novella, A Golden Story .

Aldan co-founded, with Richard Miller, the Tiber Press in 1953 and published and edited Folder Magazine of Literature and Art (1953 to 1959), an influential magazine featuring the poetry of New York School poets and the art of many notable artists. In 1959, she published the anthology A New Folder: Americans: Poems and Drawings . Aldan also co-edited, with Anaïs Nin, the poetry magazine Two Cities (1961 to 1962).

Throughout her career, Aldan contributed to many anthologies and literature magazines. She was a respected translator and published translations of works by Stéphane Mallarmé, Anaïs Nin, Albert Steffen, and Rudolf Steiner. In 1955 she made the 8mm color film, Once Upon an El , that featured several notable artists, writers, and composers protesting the demolition of New York City's Third Avenue elevated railway. For thirty-five years, Aldan taught at the School of Industrial Art (presently the High School of Art and Design) in New York City, where her students included Gerard Malanga, Jackie Curtis, Art Spiegelman, Tony Bennett, Calvin Klein, and Harvey Fierstein. Her former students cite her as a major influence in their identity and evolution as artists. Aldan died in New York City in 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Daisy Aldan Papers document the professional and personal life of poet, editor, educator, translator, and filmmaker Daisy Aldan. The papers consist of personal and professional correspondence, drafts of writings, writings of others, notebooks, diaries, teaching material, artwork, audiovisual material, photographs, printed material, and personal papers spanning the years 1919 to 2000.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into twenty groupings: I. August 1983 Acquisition. II. April 1989 Acquisition. III. April 1990 Acquisition. IV. July 1990 Acquisition. V. July 1990 Acquisition. VI. February 1991 Acquisition. VII. July 1992 Acquisition. VII. November 1992 Acquisition. VIII. November 1992 Acquisition. IX. November 1992 Acquisition. X. November 1992 Acquisition. XI. May 1993 Acquisition. XII. June 1993 Acquisition. XIII. May 1995 Acquisition. XIV. December 1995 Acquisition. XV. November 1997 Acquisition. XVI. February 1998 Acquisition. XVII. July 1998 Acquisition. XVIII. October 1999 Acquisitions. XIX. December 2000 Acquisition. XX. June 2005 Acquisition.

Material within this collection has been organized by acquisition reflecting the fact that the collection has been acquired in increments over time. Researchers should note that material within each acquisition overlaps with/or relates to material found in other acquisitions. For instance, correspondence and writings can be found in all twenty groupings. In order to locate all relevant material within this collection, researchers will need to consult each acquisition described in the Collection Contents section.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Former call number: Uncat ZA Aldan.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This material is organized under four headings: Correspondence, Writings, Photographs, and Printed Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, writing drafts and related material, photographs, and printed material. Includes drafts of and printed material relating to Aldan's novella, A Golden Story ; galley proofs of The Destruction of Cathedrals and Other Poems ; photographs for A New Folder: Americans: Poems and Drawings , edited by Aldan; and printed material on various topics.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Former call number: Uncat MSS 95.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized under four headings: Correspondence, Writings, Other Papers, and Audiovisual Materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence with various individuals, including Diana Cohen, Gerard Malanga, and Elaine Upton. Printed material, notes, clippings and lists that were among the correspondence were removed and are filed at the end of the correspondence. Writings include various drafts of poems and other writings by Aldan; written interviews conducted by Aldan with Anaïs Nin, Arthur Adamov, and Robert McDermott; lectures on Raoul Ratnowski and Stéphane Mallarmé; the typescript for Aldan's film Once Upon an El ; Aldan's translations of others' writing into English; notebooks and diaries; and writings of others, including Diana Cohen, Albert Steffen, and poems by Aldan's students. Other writings included unsorted and unidentified writings that include book reviews, notes, poems, research material on Anaïs Nin and Stéphane Mallarmé, school papers, and short stories.

Other papers include personal papers, photographs of various individuals and events, printed material, and artwork and objects owned by Aldan. Audiovisual material consists of film, sound recordings and video recordings. Film includes the original 8mm color film of Aldan's Once Upon an El , and various 8mm and 16mm reels. Sound recordings are reel-to-reel tapes, including the original sound elements of Once Upon an El , audiocassettes, and record albums. Sound recordings primarily contain various readings, radio programs, and music. Video recordings include VHS, Betamax, and U-matic tapes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A note found with this audiotape reel reads: "Contemporary Spanish Poetry", Daisy Aldan & Tana De Gomez. A typewritten note, dated 1959-03-17 from Daisy Aldan to Anais Nin is included with this audiotape reel. It reads: Dear Anais Nin, Thanks so much for your letter. I still feel bad about the books, and one of the reasons I haven't pursued Clara further is that I don't know her address out of town where she moved some time ago. One of these days, I will try to find out if Jason has a studio in New York and as soon as I do, I'll let you know. I also feel terrible that you expected to hear from me and didn't. When you get to know me better, you will see that thoughtlessness of that kind is not part of my nature. First, you went to California, then I went off on an extended trip to Europe, Greece, Africa, and so on. Then, I was so involved in all kinds of things...and so it went. Forgive me. As for the thesis, I hope to complete it this year. In any case, I think we ought to know each other better since we are both involved in similar projects and interests. Of course, you may have my mailing list - I have an excellent one now. I cannot, however, let it out of my hands at this moment. But you may feel free to come up here at any time and copy it, if you wish. Unless you have another idea. Perhaps you can spend a few hours one day soon. Simply come, make yourself at home and copy. I know how tedious it is. I have wasted and wastedd hours on such ugly details...but how well you must understand all the little things involved in running one's own press. Thanks for offering yours. One of these days, I hope I may come and copy it. Yes, I purchased a copy of your new HOUSE OF INCEST as soon as it came out. I met Val Telberg at Nell "laine's party (I had known him before), and he told me about it. The next day I picked it up at the Eighth Street Book Store. When we meet (you notice I say when, for it seems inevitable), you will tell me about purchasing your other books. I am enclosing a check for sbuscription to TWO CITIES at 40 percent discount. Under separate cover I am sending you copies of FOLDER and the COUP DE DES. I hope you enjoy them. I am no longer publishing the magazine as a magazine, but plan to publish only books. Therefore the new book of American poems and drawings will be called A NEW FOLDER. The manuscript is complete so at this moment it would be unwise to send the poems you receive to me. If YOU have any poetry of your own, however, I'd like to include you. Perhaps a prose poem. Let me know soon, for it means making room for it. I have these extra few days for I am waiting for the introduction which Wallace Fowlie is doing. I look forward to hearing from you. At any rate, come to tea or some such thing. Do let me know when you are free to do so. I remember our meeting with great pleasure. Cordially, Daisy Aldan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There is a handwritten poem and note, dated 1976-04-10, included with the audiocassette that reads: Away then, I am lock'd in one of them, If you do love me, you will find me out. Nerissa and the rest, stand all aloof, let music sound while he doth make his choice, then if he lose, he makes a swanlike end, fading in music. Mer V: Portia, III, 2, 44. And watch the fleeting white clouds of spring, they, sometimes do deceive. For Easter and Passover, Deepest love, Diana Cohen
Channel 13 - film mag.; narrator: Louis Jordan.
